results.title: Backdrop for a play
results.brief_description: Shows the activities of a group of children who prepare thw backdrop, scenery and costumes and act out the fairy tale “Puss in Boots”, against a background of a deserted colonial mansion in the midlands of Tasmania.

results.title: Backbone of the club
results.brief_description:
They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

Backbone of the club

STORY CREDITS
Detail
Backbone of the Club
A film by Malcolm McKinnon
Football Stories from Country Victoria, An initiative of the Victorian Country Football League and the State Library of Victoria, 2007

Contributors

Terms of use
Contact the copyright holder or content contributor(s) listed at the bottom of the story home page.

Copyright
Malcolm McKinnon, 2006.

They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

Further Information
TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

The ladies’ committee is the main fundraiser for the club. We do a lot of catering. Over the years, we’ve done lots of weddings, and we’ll do anything to raise money, any sort of function that we can run in this room.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

We raise about $26,000 to $28,000, depending on what functions we have through the years. And the club, you know, they just couldn’t survive without that money.

We have tea every Thursday night in the football season. We usually start the pre-season. All the players come in. Committees, supporters— anybody’s welcome. And home games, we just run the canteens. And I start early, about quarter past 7:00, every Saturday, and the others come in about 8:00.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

Backbone of the club

STORY CREDITS
Detail
Backbone of the Club
A film by Malcolm McKinnon
Football Stories from Country Victoria, An initiative of the Victorian Country Football League and the State Library of Victoria, 2007

They’re tireless workers for the cause. The Ladies’ Committee of the Shepparton Football Club serve up endless meals on a Thursday night and cater for weddings, parties, anything in order to keep their club afloat.

Thank you to Val Dominelli, Jan Enders, Roe Harrap, and Tom Greenaway.

Further Information
TRANSCRIPT

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: I joined the ladies’ committee in 1956. I was a very quiet, shy, retiring girl, and my mum brought me along to join the ladies’ committee. We both joined at the same time. And I’ve been on the committee ever since.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

The ladies’ committee is the main fundraiser for the club. We do a lot of catering. Over the years, we’ve done lots of weddings, and we’ll do anything to raise money, any sort of function that we can run in this room.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

We raise about $26,000 to $28,000, depending on what functions we have through the years. And the club, you know, they just couldn’t survive without that money.

We have tea every Thursday night in the football season. We usually start the pre-season. All the players come in. Committees, supporters— anybody’s welcome. And home games, we just run the canteens. And I start early, about quarter past 7:00, every Saturday, and the others come in about 8:00.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

JAN ENDERS: I’ve had three sons play over the years. And I get on well with the ladies, so I’ll turn up and help. We never miss the footy. We like away games because we can watch. Home games, I have most to do with the lolly stall and keeping the drinks in the fridge and backing up in the kitchen. We sometimes see the last quarter. Don’t see much else.

[SEWING MACHINE WHIRRING]

I do all the sewing, and if there’s any repairs, I take them home, bring them back Saturday morning. Our thirds and reserves won last year, and we’ve always let them have their jumpers. So you order your jumpers very early and you don’t know what players you’re going to have in sizes. So I’ve probably sewed on 100 numbers prior to the start of the season.

ROE HARRAP: I started off going with a guy who played here, ended up marrying him, and now my children are playing here. So yeah, it really is a family affair.

[LAUGHTER]

Women are at backbone s of the football club here. I believe that women play a huge role in country football. And particularly here, if he didn’t have the women behind the club, they wouldn’t be where they are now.

[PLATES CLATTERING]

VAL DOMINELLI: Oh, I love the club, and I love all the people. We’re all good friends. Actually, last week we were very short in the seconds. I got named as an emergency on the bench.

[LAUGHTER]

But this way, I think I got more players back. I said, well, just get me some boots and I’ll be right.

group_siblings.title: Looking for a game at Lake Tyers

results.title: Backbeat (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: PolyGram, Scala, Channel Four Films, Finola Dwyer, Stephen Woolley and Iain Softley
results.brief_description: When people remember the Beatles, they think of John, Paul, George and Ringo. However in the early days, the Fab Four were five, when Stuart Sutcliffe played alongside the legendary musicians. Sutcliffe (Stephen Dorff) had only a passing interest in music and a passion for painting. For his best friend, John Lennon (Ian Hart), Rock’n’Roll was the only art. “Backbeat” tells the true and tragic story of their friendship, the music, the woman who came between them and the wild times they shared when their innocence was lost. The legend was born.
results.creator_credit_for_label: PolyGram, Scala, Channel Four Films, Finola Dwyer, Stephen Woolley and Iain Softley

results.title: Back to work
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
Explores mothers returning to the workforce. Examines issues such as the costs of returning to the workforce, reasons for returning and childcare for preschool and school age children.

results.title: Back to the past: Westbourne Grammar School
results.brief_description:
Back to the Past or “Screening Melbourne” is designed to encourage students to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. In the program Students become actors in a sci-fi time travel film story during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a historical Melbourne setting, engage with a screening program featuring historical Melbourne footage and participate in a related discussion
learn some simple editing skills while they create a digital ‘Melbourne travelogue’
Back to the Past aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts to target particular audiences. Students in Years 3-4 learn about concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, and angles as well as some of the features of documentary and blue-screen technology.
Features Charles “Bud” Tingwell

results.title: Back to the past (April 2006)
results.brief_description:
“Back to the Past” is a program for primary schools to learn scripting, production and performance skills using virtual set technology. Starring Charles “Bud Tingwell ” as a time travelling scientist, BTTP sends students back in time to historical Melbourne using archival footage, animation and green screen technology.
Back to the Past or “Screening Melbourne” is designed to encourage students to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. In the program Students become actors in a sci-fi time travel film story during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a historical Melbourne setting, engage with a screening program featuring historical Melbourne footage and participate in a related discussion
learn some simple editing skills while they create a digital ‘Melbourne travelogue’
Back to the Past aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts to target particular audiences. Students in Years 3-4 learn about concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, and angles as well as some of the features of documentary and blue-screen technology.

results.title: Back to the future
results.creator_credit: Amblin Entertainment, Bob Gale, Neil Canton and Robert Zemeckis
results.brief_description: Marty McFly (Michael J Fox) and Doc (Christopher Lloyd) have to save the present by going back to the future in this classic from the 1980s.

constellations_other.name: Obviously the time continuum has been disrupted...again and again and again!
constellations_other.description: Eadweard Muybridge was able to capture time and play it back again creating endless time paradoxes where subjects are destined to repeat their previous actions. Filmmakers have since explored such notions via time travel narratives questioning destiny, fate and choice.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Amblin Entertainment, Bob Gale, Neil Canton and Robert Zemeckis
results.description: Michael J. Fox stars as Marty McFly, transported by his friend Doc’s time machine to 1955. Marty rubs shoulders with a much younger version of his parents and sees a side to them he never knew existed. The only problem is that the car responsible for sending him back to 1955 has run out of the plutonium required to fuel the car. Marty must convince Doc that his idea for a time machine, conceived in 1955 was a reality in the 1980s. As a further complication, Marty must ensure his parents-to-be meet and fall in love.
description_for_label: Michael J. Fox stars as Marty McFly, transported by his friend Doc’s time machine to 1955. Marty rubs shoulders with a much younger version of his parents and sees a side to them he never knew existed. Marty must convince Doc that his idea for a time machine, conceived in 1955 was a reality in the 1980s. As a further complication, Marty must ensure his parents-to-be meet and fall in love.

results.title: Back to life
results.creator_credit: Al Kane Productions and Al Kane
results.brief_description: A skilled factory worker suffers a nervous breakdown as a result of tensions and personality conflicts on the job and enters a mental hospital. He is diagnosed as a schizophrenic-paranoiac type. Calm, psychotherapy and occupational therapy restore him to good health. Through the support of friends, family, a social worker and a rehabilitation worker he adjusts to a normal life and is able to return to his job.
